urn:contentItem:6GGG-K843-RTT8-N2WT-00000-00Universidad Tecnica Particular de Loja Researchers Reveal New Findings on Physics (Towards Integrated Fire Management: Strengthening Forest Fire Legislation and Policies in the Andean Community of Nations)2025-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisPHYSICSUniversidad Tecnica Particular de Loja Researchers Reveal New Findings on Physics (Towards Integrated Fire Management: Strengthening Forest Fire Legislation and Policies in the Andean Community of Nations)


2025 AUG 12 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- A new study on physics is now available. According to news reporting out of the Universidad Tecnica Particular de Loja by NewsRx editors, research stated, "This study analyzes forest fire legislation and policies in the Andean Community of Nations (ACN)-Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia-focusing on prevention and control."


Financial supporters for this research include Universidad Tecnica Particular De Loja.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Universidad Tecnica Particular de Loja: "Using a comparative law approach, similarities, differences, and implementation challenges were identified. Ecuador and Peru have more comprehensive legal structures, while Colombia's is simpler, and Bolivia falls in between. To address these gaps, this study proposes an Andean Directive for Integrated Fire Management (ADIFM) to harmonize policies and incorporate fire ecology, ancestral knowledge, education, monitoring technologies, and post-fire restoration. This regulatory framework, tailored to Andean ecological and sociocultural conditions, would optimize fire management and strengthen ecosystem resilience. Additionally, harmonizing sanctions and regulations at the regional level would ensure more coherent and effective governance."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The ADIFM would provide strategic guidance for policymakers, fostering sustainable fire management and environmental restoration across Andean ecosystems."
For more information on this research see: Towards Integrated Fire Management: Strengthening Forest Fire Legislation and Policies in the Andean Community of Nations. Fire, 2025,8(7):266. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8070266.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Liliana Correa-Quezada, Departamento de Ciencias Juridicas, Universidad Tecnica Particular de Loja, San Cayetano Alto S, N, Loja C.P. 1101608, Ecuador. Additional authors for this research include Victor Carrion-Correa, Carolina Lopez, Daniel Segura, Vinicio Carrion-Paladines.
Keywords for this news article include: Universidad Tecnica Particular de Loja, Physics.

urn:contentItem:6GNK-4NK3-RWXW-52DP-00000-00They articulate actions for the first regional drill for forest fire in Awajun2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisThey articulate actions for the first regional drill for forest fire in Awajun

It will be on Friday, September 12 at 3:00 p.m. In the Native Shampuyacu community, Awajun district, Rioja provinceWith the objective of coordinating the execution of the first regional fire by fire, scheduled for Friday, September 12 at 3:00 p.m. In the Native Community of Shampuyacu, Awajun District, Rioja Province, the Regional Government of San Martin (Goresam), through the Regional Office of National Security and Defense and the Regional Emergency Operations Center (COER), in coordination with the District Municipality of Awajun, developed a working meeting with district, provincial authorities and representatives of various institutions.

During the meeting, the Coer San Martin highlighted the importance of these exercises as joint preparation and response spaces, in compliance with Resolution No. 001-2025-PCM/SGRD, which provides for the realization of simulations and simulations nationwide. Likewise, the work plan was reviewed, defining responsibilities, logistics resources, command positions and intervention areas to guarantee the success of the exercise.

In addition, Coer San Martin stressed that this drill will be an opportunity to evaluate response protocols, improve inter -institutional articulation capacity and sensitize the population about the importance of prevention against forest fires, one of the main risks that affect the region.

Representatives of the Army of Peru, National Police of Peru, Sernanp, Indeci, Regional Environmental Authority (ARA), International Conservation, the Micro -Rred of Health of Bajo Naranjillo, the District Municipality of Awajun, the Provincial Municipality of Rioja, Serenazgo staff and communal leaders of Shampuyacu, who ratified their commitment to actively collaborate in the simulation in the simulation.

In this way, the regional government reaffirms its commitment to protect life, health and environment, promoting a culture of prevention and resilience in the San Martin region.

urn:contentItem:6GC9-1KV3-RTPH-S1P4-00000-00Research from Yozgat Bozok University in the Area of Applied Sciences Described (Hybrid Backbone-Based Deep Learning Model for Early Detection of Forest Fire Smoke)2025-07-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - APPLIED SCIENCESResearch from Yozgat Bozok University in the Area of Applied Sciences Described (Hybrid Backbone-Based Deep Learning Model for Early Detection of Forest Fire Smoke)


2025 JUL 28 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- Research findings on applied sciences are discussed in a new report. According to news originating from Yozgat, Turkey, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Accurate forest fire detection is critical for the timely intervention and mitigation of environmental disasters."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Yozgat Bozok University: "It is very important to intervene in forest fires before major damage occurs by using smoke data. This study proposes a novel deep learning-based approach that significantly enhances the accuracy of fire detection by incorporating advanced feature extraction techniques. Through rigorous experiments and comprehensive evaluations, our method outperforms existing approaches, demonstrating its effectiveness in detecting fires at an early stage. The proposed approach leverages convolutional neural networks to automatically identify fire signatures from remote sensing images, offering a reliable and efficient solution for forest fire monitoring. A total of 30 different object detection models, including the proposed model, were run with the extended Wildfire Smoke dataset, and the results were compared. As a result of extensive experiments, it was observed that the proposed model gave the best result among all models, with a test mAP value of 96.9%."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Our findings not only contribute to the advancement of fire detection technologies, but also underscore the importance of deep learning in addressing real-world environmental challenges."
For more information on this research see: Hybrid Backbone-Based Deep Learning Model for Early Detection of Forest Fire Smoke. Applied Sciences, 2025,15(13):7178. (Applied Sciences - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/applsci). The publisher for Applied Sciences is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/app15137178.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Gokalp Cinarer, Department of Computer Engineering, Faculty of Engineering-Architecture, Yozgat Bozok University, 66100 Yozgat, Turkey.
Keywords for this news article include: Yozgat Bozok University, Yozgat, Turkey, Eurasia, Applied Sciences, Science.

urn:contentItem:6H16-KHJ3-RTC2-P2MJ-00000-00New Findings from Central South University of Forestry and Technology Update Understanding of Technology (A Novel Approach for Inverting Forest Fuel Moisture Content Utilizing Multi-source Remote Sensing and Deep Learning)2025-10-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYNew Findings from Central South University of Forestry and Technology Update Understanding of Technology (A Novel Approach for Inverting Forest Fuel Moisture Content Utilizing Multi-source Remote Sensing and Deep Learning)


2025 OCT 20 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Researchers detail new data in Technology. According to news reporting originating in Changsha, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Fuel Moisture Content (FMC) is a critical indicator for assessing forest fire risk and formulating early warning strategies, as its spatiotemporal dynamics directly influence the accuracy of fire danger rating. To improve the accuracy of forest FMC estimation, this study proposes an innovative deep learning method integrating multi-source remote sensing data."


Funders for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China, Hunan Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars.
The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from the Central South University of Forestry and Technology, "By combining the global feature extraction capability of the Transformer architecture with the local temporal modeling advantages of Gated Recurrent Units (GRU) (referred to as the Transformer-GRU model), a high-precision FMC estimation framework is established. The study focuses on forested areas in California, USA, utilizing ground-measured FMC data alongside multi-source remote sensing datasets from MODIS, Sentinel-1, and Sentinel-2. A systematic comparison was conducted among Transformer-GRU model, standalone Transformer models, single GRU models, and two classical machine learning models (Random Forest, RF, and Support Vector Regression, SVR). Additionally, forward feature selection was employed to evaluate the performance of different models and feature combinations. The results demonstrate that (1) All models effectively utilize the derived features from multi-source remote sensing data, confirming the significant enhancement of multi-source data fusion for forest FMC estimation; (2) The Transformer-GRU model outperforms other models in capturing the nonlinear relationship between FMC and remote sensing data, achieving superior estimation accuracy (R2 = 0.79, MAE = 8.70%, RMSE = 11.44%, rRMSE = 12.60%); (3) The spatiotemporal distribution patterns of forest FMC in California generated by the Transformer-GRU model align well with regional geographic characteristics and climatic variability, while exhibiting a strong relationship with historical wildfire occurrences."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The proposed Transformer-GRU model provides a novel approach for high-precision FMC estimation, offering reliable technical support for dynamic forest fire risk early warning and resource management."
For more information on this research see: A Novel Approach for Inverting Forest Fuel Moisture Content Utilizing Multi-source Remote Sensing and Deep Learning. Forests, 2025;16(9):1423. Forests can be contacted at: Mdpi, St Alban-Anlage 66, Ch-4052 Basel, Switzerland.
Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Cui Zhou, Central South University of Forestry and Technology, Sch Adv Interdisciplinary Studies, Changsha 410004, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Wenjun Wang, Junxiang Zhang, Yuanzong Li, Zhenyu Chen and Yongfeng Luo.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.3390/f16091423. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-KX73-RTM6-C1T4-00000-00A forest fire in Granada forces to deploy a large device to contain the flames2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisA forest fire in Granada forces to deploy a large device to contain the flames


The flames were seen five minutes after nine o'clock on Saturday night and, a few moments later, and began to devour the hillside next to the tunnels of Serrallo, a neighborhood of Granada. The forest fire that broke out under a restaurant in Huétor Vega kept on tenterhooks the residents of the capital and Cenes de la Vega and forced to deploy a large device that at midnight was trying to stop, with the help of a change of wind, the spread of fire along the mountain parallel to the Genil.


Due to the size of the fire, 30 people had to be evacuated from the Balcón del Genil restaurant. "A gust of air came and it went up like foam, tremendous tongues of fire," assured a witness. "A small fire started in the viewpoint and a few minutes later the flames surrounded the restaurant. We went out with hoses and whatever we could to extinguish and contain the fire while the firemen arrived. Fortunately the fire did not reach the building, but it was close," said Paloma, a worker at the establishment.
The neighbors surrounded the fire gap in fear that it would reach their homes. "We have come to see what is happening, we feel calmer if we are here. We have been told that everything is under control," explained a resident of Balcón del Genil.
Julia and her family had just parked the car and were heading to the restaurant for dinner when, "in a matter of seconds, the smoke turned into flames." "In that area there are some huge trees that started to burn, moving from left to right. All the people who were inside have been coming out to see what was happening and the cooks have been turning off the lights, the gas cylinders, the electric plates, taking measures to avoid other dangers," he shared. "The heat is tremendous, as if you get close to the chimney."
All the way to the top
At the stroke of midnight, in the area were still working two trucks, a mother truck, four environmental agents, eleven firefighters from the southern park of the capital, two from the northern park and four Infoca retainers. They waited for the fire crowned the top, where the troops were waiting to cut the flames in an area near the water tanks. The descending wind played in favor of the extinction, as the fire returned to the area already burned. The smoke completely obscured the view of the city from the seat of the fire. To facilitate the work and due to the proximity of the flames, the A-395 was cut and traffic was diverted through Cenes.
On the ground worked to try to quell the flames Firefighters of Granada, the group of forest action, personnel and means of Infoca, Civil Protection volunteers, Local Police of Huétor Vega and Local Police of Granada. The coordinator of the command post of the Infoca plan explained that in principle would maintain the deployment throughout the night and would make timely relays. The most worrying flank was the left one. Other outbreaks were already stabilized although in some areas there were small outbreaks.

urn:contentItem:6H64-2R63-RTV6-646B-00000-00Nanjing Forestry University Researcher Details New Studies and Findings in the Area of Support Vector Machines (Design of L1-OCSVM Model and Its Application in Forestry Object Detection)2025-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisSUPPORT VECTOR MACHINESNanjing Forestry University Researcher Details New Studies and Findings in the Area of Support Vector Machines (Design of L1-OCSVM Model and Its Application in Forestry Object Detection)


2025 NOV 12 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Robotics & Machine Learning Daily News Daily News -- Fresh data on are presented in a new report. According to news reporting out of Jiangsu, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "One-Class Classification (OCC) techniques, such as Support Vector Domain Description (SVDD) and One Class Support Vector Machines (OCSVM), have received widespread attention in application fields such as computer vision, machine learning, and biometric recognition."


Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing Forestry University: "Most current OCC models are designed based on the L2 norm; therefore, issues such as insufficient sparse solutions, noise sensitivity, and the need for second-order or higher optimization persist, making real-time object detection difficult. To address this issue, this study proposes a one-class classifier called L1-OCSVM by replacing the interval term of OCSVM's L2 norm with the L1 norm. This substitution not only inherits the large interval principle of Support Vector Machines (SVM) but also leads to first-order optimization problems. However, owing to the introduction of the L1 norm, the feature samples in the nonlinear L1-OCSVM model no longer appear in pairs like the L2 norm, and therefore they cannot be replaced by the inner product of the L2 norm. Thus, an equivalent optimization strategy is provided, which directly minimizes the L1 norm term of the variable, resulting in extremely sparse solutions that are very conducive to real-time detection."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Experiments on non-rigid object detection in forestry problems, such as forest fire, forest smoke, and tree crowns, using unmanned aerial vehicle images and ground remote sensing images verify the advantages of L1-OCSVM in object detection accuracy, sparsity, and real-time detection."
For more information on this research see: Design of L1-OCSVM Model and Its Application in Forestry Object Detection. Jisuanji gongcheng, 2025,51(7):375-384. The publisher for Jisuanji gongcheng is Editorial Office of Computer Engineering.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.19678/j.issn.1000-3428.0068679.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting YANG Xubing LIU Xudong, College of Information Science and Technology, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, Jiangsu, People's Republic of China.

urn:contentItem:6G77-K543-RSC6-52GM-00000-00Hubei University Reports Findings in Science (Development and analysis of a forest fire emission inventory in China considering daily variation patterns)2025-07-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisSCIENCEHubei University Reports Findings in Science (Development and analysis of a forest fire emission inventory in China considering daily variation patterns)


2025 JUL 09 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Daily China News -- New research on Science is the subject of a report. According to news reporting originating from Wuhan, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fire emission inventories constitute a fundamental data source for air quality modeling and investigations into the environmental impacts of forest fires. Current datasets predominantly offer daily or monthly emission estimates derived from Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) fire products."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Hubei University, "However, detailed analyses of forest fire emission characteristics at the hourly resolution remain limited in China. In this study, we developed an hourly emission inventory for Chinese forest fires from 2016 to 2022 by integrating MODIS, Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS), and Himawari-8 active fire data, while incorporating diurnal variation patterns of forest fire activity. Utilizing this inventory, the spatial and temporal distributions of forest fire emissions across China were analyzed. The findings indicate that forest fires consumed approximately 95,495 Gg of dry matter during the study period, with the majority concentrated in the southern, southwestern, and northeastern forest regions, accounting for 44.3%, 32.5%, and 18.2% of the total emissions, respectively. Emission hotspots in the southern forest region were predominantly located in provinces, such as Guangxi, Guangdong, Fujian, Jiangxi, and Hunan. In the southwestern forest region, hotspots were concentrated in southern Yunnan and Sichuan, while in the northeastern forest region, they were distributed across northeastern Inner Mongolia, northwestern Heilongjiang, and central Jilin and Liaoning. Months with higher forest fire emissions in China occur in February, March, April, October, November, and December. Significant seasonal differences exist in the diurnal variation of fire emissions across different forest regions. The Northeast Forest Region exhibits distinct emission peaks during spring and autumn, with peak times occurring at 13:00 and 12:00, respectively. The Southern and Southwest Forest Regions show similar diurnal variation characteristics. During winter, their peak emission times occur at 13:00-14:00 and 14:00-15:00, respectively. In spring and autumn, both regions display two emission troughs and three emission peaks. The occurrence times of these troughs and peaks in the Southwest Forest Region lag approximately one hour behind those in the Southern Forest Region."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "These results provide critical insights into the spatiotemporal characteristics of forest fire emissions in China and offer a robust foundation for further research on the precise quantification of the air quality impacts associated with forest fires."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Development and analysis of a forest fire emission inventory in China considering daily variation patterns. Environmental Pollution, 2025:126720. Environmental Pollution can be contacted at: Elsevier Sci Ltd, 125 London Wall, London, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Environmental Pollution - www.journals.elsevier.com/environmental-pollution/)
The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Jiaxin Liu, Hubei University, School of Resources and Environment, Wuhan, 430062, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Rong Li, Mingda Zhang, Congwu Huang, Sihan Zhao, Meigen Zhang and Liangfu Chen.
Publisher contact information for the journal Environmental Pollution is: Elsevier Sci Ltd, 125 London Wall, London, England.

urn:contentItem:6H5X-4703-RYC5-B1WY-00000-00Research in the Area of Sensor Research Reported from Ulster University (Edge-Based Autonomous Fire and Smoke Detection Using MobileNetV2)2025-11-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - SENSOR RESEARCHResearch in the Area of Sensor Research Reported from Ulster University (Edge-Based Autonomous Fire and Smoke Detection Using MobileNetV2)


2025 NOV 11 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Fresh data on sensor research are presented in a new report. According to news originating from London, United Kingdom, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires pose significant threats to ecosystems, human life, and the global climate, necessitating rapid and reliable detection systems."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Ulster University: "Traditional fire detection approaches, including sensor networks, satellite monitoring, and centralized image analysis, often suffer from delayed response, high false positives, and limited deployment in remote areas. Recent deep learning-based methods offer high classification accuracy but are typically computationally intensive and unsuitable for low-power, real-time edge devices. This study presents an autonomous, edge-based forest fire and smoke detection system using a lightweight MobileNetV2 convolutional neural network. The model is trained on a balanced dataset of fire, smoke, and non-fire images and optimized for deployment on resource-constrained edge devices. The system performs near real-time inference, achieving a test accuracy of 97.98% with an average end-to-end prediction latency of 0.77 s per frame (approximately 1.3 FPS) on the Raspberry Pi 5 edge device. Predictions include the class label, confidence score, and timestamp, all generated locally without reliance on cloud connectivity, thereby enhancing security and robustness against potential cyber threats."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed solution maintains high predictive performance comparable to state-of-the-art methods while providing efficient, offline operation suitable for real-world environmental monitoring and early wildfire mitigation. This approach enables cost-effective, scalable deployment in remote forest regions, combining accuracy, speed, and autonomous edge processing for timely fire and smoke detection."
For more information on this research see: Edge-Based Autonomous Fire and Smoke Detection Using MobileNetV2. Sensors, 2025,25(20):6419. (Sensors - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/sensors). The publisher for Sensors is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/s25206419.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Dilshod Sharobiddinov, Department of Computer Science, Ulster University, London Branch Campus, St. James' House, 10 Rosebery Avenue, Holborn, London EC1R 4TF, United Kingdom. Additional authors for this research include Hafeez Ur Rehman Siddiqui, Adil Ali Saleem, Gerardo Mendez Mezquita, Debora Libertad Ramirez Vargas, Isabel de la Torre Diez.
Keywords for this news article include: Ulster University, London, United Kingdom, Europe, Cybersecurity, Sensor Research, Technology.

urn:contentItem:6GPW-PYR3-RRX5-V1CY-00000-00Researchers' from University of Quebec Report Details of New Studies and Findings in the Area of Climate Change (Climate change and transformation in forest fire regimes: an opportunity for the implementation of assisted migration of tree ...)2025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEResearchers' from University of Quebec Report Details of New Studies and Findings in the Area of Climate Change (Climate change and transformation in forest fire regimes: an opportunity for the implementation of assisted migration of tree ...)


2025 SEP 11 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily -- Investigators discuss new findings in climate change. According to news reporting from Quebec, Canada, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Climate change is intensifying fire regimes in boreal forests, leading to ecological disruption and raising concerns about forest resilience and post-disturbance recovery."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from University of Quebec: "Altered fire dynamics creates novel opportunities for implementing adaptive silviculture for climate change, including assisted migration, the intentional movement and establishment of tree species or tree populations outside their current range of distribution to better match anticipated future climates. Here, we examine how the increasing frequency, severity, and spatial extent of Canadian boreal wildfires can serve as strategic windows for introducing climate-resilient tree species and genotypes. We review how fire influences the availability and suitability of post-fire sites for assisted migration, highlighting how fire-induced changes in soil abiotic and biotic properties may facilitate or hinder the establishment of relocated tree species. While fire can simplify site preparation, reduce biotic competition, and temporarily enhance soil nutrient availability, it may also degrade soil structure by consuming or altering soil organic matter and increasing soil susceptibility to erosion and disrupt essential mycorrhizal associations. We argue that assisted migration of tree species can be a proactive silvicultural tool when used in areas with regeneration failure or where future climate conditions are likely to exceed the tolerance limits of native species."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Whilst scientific evidence remains limited on the regeneration success of migrated species and genotypes in post-fire environments, we argue for an integrated adaptation strategy that combines natural regeneration with targeted assisted migration interventions, guided by local site conditions, genetic considerations, and policy support, to build resilient boreal forests under changing disturbance regimes."
For more information on this research see: Climate change and transformation in forest fire regimes: an opportunity for the implementation of assisted migration of tree species in the Canadian boreal forest?. Silva Fennica, 2025,59(2). (Silva Fennica - https://silvafennica.fi/). The publisher for Silva Fennica is Finnish Society of Forest Science.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.14214/sf.25031.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Simon Lebel Desrosiers, Laboratoire sur la science des donnees, University of Quebec (TELUQ), 5800, rue Saint-Denis, bureau 1105, Montreal, Quebec H2S 3L5, Canada. Additional authors for this research include Nicolas Belanger, Evelyne Thiffault, Nelson Thiffault.

urn:contentItem:6H5X-4703-RYC5-B0VT-00000-00Study Data from Guangdong Academy of Forestry Update Understanding of Physics (Fire Extinction Analysis and OH-PLIF Visualization of the Methane-Air Premixed Laminar Flame Interacting with the Downward Water Mist)2025-11-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisPHYSICSStudy Data from Guangdong Academy of Forestry Update Understanding of Physics (Fire Extinction Analysis and OH-PLIF Visualization of the Methane-Air Premixed Laminar Flame Interacting with the Downward Water Mist)


2025 NOV 11 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- New research on physics is the subject of a new report. According to news reporting out of Guangzhou, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "In this study, a McKenna burner made for calibration is used to generate the laminar flame with the equivalence ratio of 0.78~2.0."


Financial supporters for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China; Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Silviculture, Protection, And Utilization “research on The Mechanism of Water Mist Fire Extinguishing For Early Forest Fire Response”; Guangdong Province Forestry Science And Technology Innovation Project; Shandong Provincial Natural Science Foundation.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Guangdong Academy of Forestry: "The effect of the downward water mist spray on the extinction of the methane-air premixed laminar flame is investigated using hydroxide planar laser-induced fluorescence (OH-PLIF). The variation of the water flow rate for flame extinction is analyzed by the hydroxyl radical concentration distribution and the effective water mist flow rate. The required water flow rate for flame extinction is higher in the cases of rich fuel mixtures. The maximum critical extinguishing water flow rate for the methane-air premixed laminar flame is about 9.55 L/min under the conditions of water mist spray with a 45° solid cone spray angle and a 24 mm droplet size. Furthermore, the evolution of OH-PLIF flame behavior revealed that the stability of the hydroxyl radical concentration at the base of the flame mainly contributed to the flame extinction."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This study provides a theoretical reference for the critical extinguishing conditions of water mist in the application of an active fire suppression system."
For more information on this research see: Fire Extinction Analysis and OH-PLIF Visualization of the Methane-Air Premixed Laminar Flame Interacting with the Downward Water Mist. Fire, 2025,8(10):375. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8100375.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Yangpeng Liu, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Silviculture, Protection and Utilization, Guangdong Academy of Forestry, Guangzhou 510520, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Yufei Zhou, Yingxia Zhong, Chuanyu Pan, Guochun Li, Zepeng Wu.

urn:contentItem:6GS3-RCC3-RRJB-232G-00000-00Two new forest fires in Arequipa consumed more than 100 hectares2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisTwo new forest fires in Arequipa consumed more than 100 hectares

Two new forest fires in Arequipa consumed more than 100 hectaresFires are registered in the provinces of Caylloma and La Unión. Fires are still active.

Power outage in Arequipa scheduled by Seal this September 16 and 17: check schedules and affected areas

INDECI issues emergency alert in Arequipa: forest fire is located in the Misti foothills

Wilder Pari
Forest fires do not stop in the Arequipa region. A new fire started on the afternoon of September 15 in the district of Tisco, Caylloma province. According to the latest information from the Regional Emergency Operations Center (COER), it was not yet extinguished.


At the moment it is known that the fire consumed about 100 hectares of wild grasslands, which were used as fodder for cattle. By 9 a.m. on September 16, the fire was partially under control, but then the flames rekindled in some pockets.
WE RECOMMENDWithout Script | Phillip Butters in LR
According to local media, the mayor of Tisco, Lino Maquera, the fire was reportedly started by shepherds who set branches on fire to scare off a puma that was threatening the livestock.
At about 3:30 p.m. on September 16, theCOER Arequipa reported a new forest fire in the district of Charcana, province of La Unión, which was still active.
Forest fires in chain
These two weeks are critical for Arequipa. Last week there was a forest fire in the province of La Union that devastated 368 hectares of vegetation. This fire lasted five days. During the weekend, the fire on the slopes of the Misti volcano in the city of Arequipa consumed more than 200 hectares.
In addition, the province of Caylloma has also suffered from other forest fires in the last month, registered in the districts of Coporaque and Chivay.
It is worth remembering that forest fires represent serious ecological damage. According to Serfor personnel, it takes up to four years for the devastated land to recover. It also means the destruction of wildlife habitat.

urn:contentItem:6GB7-6253-RVJ4-22NR-00000-00Findings from Linnaeus University Yields New Data on Technology (Swedish Private Forest Owners' Experiences of Forest Fire On Their Property)2025-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYFindings from Linnaeus University Yields New Data on Technology (Swedish Private Forest Owners' Experiences of Forest Fire On Their Property)


2025 JUL 23 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Investigators discuss new findings in Technology. According to news originating from Vaxjo, Sweden, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires, or wildfires, are expected to increase due to warmer and drier summers caused by climate change. When the forest is on fire, all forest owners are by law responsible to assist the fire and rescue services."


Financial supporters for this research include Linnaeus University, Swedish Forest Agency.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Linnaeus University, "Hence, the aim of this study was to describe private forest owners' experiences of forest fires on their property. In-depth interviews were conducted and analyzed by using qualitative content analysis to describe 20 private forest owners' experiences of forest fires. The result merged in the overarching theme: 'Powerlessness in fighting the forest fire alleviates by togetherness in a desire to help and to be helped'. Meaning, a forest fire is a disaster both in economical and emotional terms, causing destruction to the forest that has been in the private forest owners' care for generations. The forest owner feels responsibility and expresses an unquestionable will to act. The invaluable support from the local community helps the forest owner to manage this difficult. However, the forest owner expects to be allowed to contribute, therefore, the fire and rescue services need a proactive plan that involves private forest owners to ensure a safe work environment for all involved. In addition, the strong and differentiated network of family and neighbors that mobilize brings strength and local knowledge important to the operation. Though worrying of new forest fires will remain, it is a burden that needs to be taken seriously."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "A positive outcome is that through collaboration, security and resilience enhances in the local community."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Swedish Private Forest Owners' Experiences of Forest Fire On Their Property. Small-scale Forestry, 2025. Small-scale Forestry can be contacted at: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands. (Springer - www.springer.com; Small-scale Forestry - www.springerlink.com/content/1873-7617/)
The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from Frida Bjorcman, Linnaeus University, Dept. of Forestry and Wood Technology, Vaxjo, Sweden. Additional authors for this research include Bengt Nilsson, Bengt Fridlund, Carina Elmqvist and Anders Svensson.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s11842-025-09589-3. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6GMP-67C3-RX64-P2SR-00000-00KOGAS Announces Gas Corporation Focuses on Forest Fire Recovery & Biodiversity Conservation2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisKOGAS Announces Gas Corporation Focuses on Forest Fire Recovery & Biodiversity Conservation

Korea Gas Corporation and National Institute of Ecology held a transplant ceremony for the endangered species, the Great Fireweed* on August 26 in Cheongsong, Gyeongsangbuk-do, in cooperation with the National Institute of Ecology to restore areas damaged by forest fires and preserve biodiversity.



- The Great Fireweed, a perennial herb belonging to the Apiaceae family, only grows around some rivers and valleys in the Gyeongsangbuk-do and Gangwon-do, and was designated as a Class II endangered species in 2012 due to a rapid decline in population due to indiscriminate habitat destruction.

- Approximately 30 people from both organizations attended the event, including Jeong Taek-ju, Director of the Carbon Neutral Environment Department at Korea Gas Corporation, and Jeong Gil-sang, Director of the Restoration Research Lab at the National Institute of Ecology.

- Korea Gas Corporation is actively creating environmental and social value by carrying out a biodiversity conservation project with the National Institute of Ecology starting in 2022 as part of its sustainable management, such as restoring the Black-faced Spoonbill and the Japanese Orchid, which are both endangered species of Korea.
- In particular, this year, we are focusing on natural ecosystem restoration activities by promoting the investigation and restoration of endangered species damage in areas damaged by large-scale forest fires in the Gyeongbuk region.

- This time, the gas corporation plans to transplant 200 fireweeds, cultivated using artificial propagation technology at the National Institute of Ecology's Endangered Species Restoration Center, to the Juwangsan Mountain area in Cheongsong-gun, and increase habitat stability and survival rate through follow-up management such as patrols and surveillance.
- In particular, the area where the event was held was a natural habitat for fireweeds in the past, but due to natural damage such as river development, wild populations are currently not found.

- A gas corporation official said, "We hope that this event will serve as an opportunity for endangered species and other biological populations to resettle in areas damaged by forest fires and restore the health of the ecosystem," and "We will continue to promote biodiversity conservation activities and strive to raise public awareness of environmental issues."

urn:contentItem:6H64-2PS3-RRKG-C38J-00000-00Data on Remote Sensing Reported by Researchers at Shandong University (HybriDet: A Hybrid Neural Network Combining CNN and Transformer for Wildfire Detection in Remote Sensing Imagery)2025-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - REMOTE SENSINGData on Remote Sensing Reported by Researchers at Shandong University (HybriDet: A Hybrid Neural Network Combining CNN and Transformer for Wildfire Detection in Remote Sensing Imagery)


2025 NOV 12 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Network Daily News -- Current study results on remote sensing have been published. According to news originating from Weihai, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Early warning systems on edge devices such as satellites and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are essential for effective forest fire prevention. Edge Intelligence (EI) enables deploying deep learning models on edge devices; however, traditional convolutional neural networks (CNNs)/Transformer-based models struggle to balance local-global context integration and computational efficiency in such constrained environments."


Funders for this research include Shandong Province Technology Innovation Guidance Plan.
Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Shandong University: "To address these challenges, this paper proposes HybriDet, a novel hybrid-architecture neural network for wildfire detection. This architecture integrates the strengths of both CNNs and Transformers to effectively capture both local and global contextual information. Furthermore, we introduce efficient attention mechanisms-Windowed Attention and Coordinate-Spatial (CS) Attention-to simultaneously enhance channel-wise and spatial-wise features in high-resolution imagery, enabling long-range dependency modeling and discriminative feature extraction. Additionally, to optimize deployment efficiency, we also apply model pruning techniques to improve generalization performance and inference speed. Extensive experimental evaluations demonstrate that HybriDet achieves superior feature extraction capabilities while maintaining high computational efficiency. The optimized lightweight variant of HybriDet has a compact model size of merely 6.45 M parameters, facilitating seamless deployment on resource-constrained edge devices. Comparative evaluations on the FASDD-UAV, FASDD-RS, and VOC datasets demonstrate that HybriDet achieves superior performance over state-of-the-art models, particularly in processing highly heterogeneous remote sensing (RS) imagery. When benchmarked against YOLOv8, HybriDet demonstrates a 6.4% enhancement in mAP50 on the FASDD-RS dataset while maintaining comparable computational complexity."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Meanwhile, on the VOC dataset and the FASDD-UAV dataset, our model improved by 3.6% and 0.2%, respectively, compared to the baseline model YOLOv8. These advancements highlight HybriDet's theoretical significance as a novel hybrid EI framework for wildfire detection, with practical implications for disaster emergency response, socioeconomic security, and ecological conservation."
For more information on this research see: HybriDet: A Hybrid Neural Network Combining CNN and Transformer for Wildfire Detection in Remote Sensing Imagery. Remote Sensing, 2025,17(20):3497. (Remote Sensing - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/remotesensing/). The publisher for Remote Sensing is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/rs17203497.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Fengming Dong, School of Mechanical, Electrical & Information Engineering, Shandong University, Weihai 264209, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Ming Wang.
Keywords for this news article include: Shandong University, Weihai, People's Republic of China, Asia, Cybersecurity, Networks, Neural Networks, Remote Sensing, Technology.

urn:contentItem:6H6J-13S3-RY1R-214K-00000-00New Findings Reported from National Institute of Technology Rourkela Describe Advances in Meteorology Hydrology and Geophysics (From Flames To Recovery: Ecosystem Resilience In Uttarakhand's 2022 Forest Fires)2025-11-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - METEOROLOGY HYDROLOGY AND GEOPHYSICSNew Findings Reported from National Institute of Technology Rourkela Describe Advances in Meteorology Hydrology and Geophysics (From Flames To Recovery: Ecosystem Resilience In Uttarakhand's 2022 Forest Fires)


2025 NOV 14 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- A new study on Science - Meteorology Hydrology and Geophysics is now available. According to news reporting from Rourkela, India, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "The foothills of the Himalaya are one of the major hotspots of forest fires in India. Forest fires during the hot-dry summer season (March-June) often cause damage to the Forest ecosystem, one of such events is the Uttarakhand fires in 2022, which seriously impacted the natural vegetation led to economic losses."


Financial support for this research came from Ministry of Earth Sciences (MoES) - India.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the National Institute of Technology Rourkela, "However, its drivers and ecosystem resilience to vegetation impacts are not well understood. Using hydroclimatic, vegetation, and fire datasets, we thoroughly examined the spatio-temporal variations and recovery of burnt vegetation. High-severity burns were concentrated in the southern regions of Uttarakhand, interpreted based on the dNBR index classes. The burned biomass calculated for the selected high severity area, showed decline (16.75%), post-fire recovery (40.85%) indicated uneven ecosystem resilience. High VPD and low soil moisture, intensified the fire risks but during monsoon onset and fire-induced rainfall helped restore soil moisture and reduce VPD, supported early vegetation recovery. The satellite observation indices observed dynamic restoration immediate after the fire event, Ashowed SAVI (from similar to 0.23-0.43) Aand VCI (from similar to 40-80), Aindicating secondary succession. Overall post-fire burned regions had SH >40% and LH <-20% but showed decline in GPP (similar to 20%) and ET (8-21%), while PET rose stronger atmospheric demand under weakened surface supply (3-19%), which the explained slow recovery."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This study highlights the importance of assessing and understanding the vegetation dynamics with providing key insights into atmospheric conditions and internal characteristics of vegetation recovery offers guidance for adapting to forest fire impacts."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: From Flames To Recovery: Ecosystem Resilience In Uttarakhand's 2022 Forest Fires. MAUSAM, 2025;76(4):1095-1112. MAUSAM can be contacted at: India Meteorological Dept, Mausam Bhawan, Lodi Rd, New Delhi, 110 003, India.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Bhishma Tyagi, National Institute of Technology Rourkela, Dept. of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences, Rourkela 769008, India. Additional authors for this research include M. S. Shyam Sunder and Shanti Shwarup Mahto.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.54302/mausam.v76i4.7086. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Rourkela, India, Asia, Meteorology Hydrology and Geophysics, Science, National Institute of Technology Rourkela.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88C3-RWV2-G4Y1-00000-00Level 1 emergency phase activated due to a forest fire in Almeria2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisLevel 1 emergency phase activated due to a forest fire in Almeria


The Minister of the Presidency, Interior, Social Dialogue and Administrative Simplification, Antonio Sanz, has raised, at 05:46 hours today, Friday, August 29, to emergency phase, operational situation 1, the Emergency Plan for Forest Fires in Andalusia (Plan Infoca) in the province of Almeria, for a fire declared in the Paraje de las Cubillas in Lubrín.


This phase is activated in those fires in which, being able to be controlled with the ordinary means and resources available in the Junta de Andalucía is estimated, by its possible evolution, the need for the implementation of measures for the protection of people and property of non-forest nature. In this case, the operation has proceeded to the preventive eviction of five people from the areas of Los Albaricos and Fuente de los Albaricos in the Almeria town of Bédar.
Infoca staff, belonging to the Emergency Agency of Andalusia (EMA), remain deployed in the area 11 groups of specialists, five vehicles and five technicians, at dawn will join the air resources. On the ground is also the Mobile Unit of Meteorology and Transmissions.
The emergency telephone number 1-1-2 began to receive notices from citizens warning of the fire about 23.00 hours yesterday Thursday and immediately alerted the Civil Guard, the Local Police, as well as firefighters and the Provincial Operational Center (COP) Infoca that moved means immediately. It has also mobilized the Emergency Group of Andalusia (GREA). Members of the provincial Civil Protection service of the Emergency Agency of Andalusia have also moved to the Advanced Command Post.
Emergency Platform
The Emergency Agency of Andalusia provides information 24 hours a day 365 days a year of fires in the region, both through the official accounts of Infoca and 1-1-2 in social networks and through the button 'forest fires in real time' which is included in the Emergency Platform for Citizenship (
The Emergency Platform for the Citizen gathers in a single site all the information of interest on emergencies managed in the autonomous community, in addition to self-protection tips or weather information, among other information of interest.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G1B3-RS1P-J4MP-00000-00The Aragonese troops work to secure the perimeter of the Barniedo de la Reina (CyL) forest fire.2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisThe Aragonese troops work to secure the perimeter of the Barniedo de la Reina (CyL) forest fire.


More than 30 professionals of the INFOAR device of the Government of Aragon continue collaborating in the extinction of the fires. In the last hours, their work has been focused on the sector of Valverde de la Sierra (León) within the Barniedo de la Reina fire. This Friday morning, the heliborne brigade of Calamocha -with its helicopter- has taken over from the brigade of Ejea de los Caballeros.


The main tasks carried out by the INFOAR troops are the securing of the perimeter by means of manual tools and, especially, the application of technical fire. This maneuver consists of generating control lines that prevent the spread of the fire, creating safe zones between the vegetation that is already affected and that which is still at risk of burning. The most outstanding difficulties in the area are the complex orography and the high vegetation fuel load, which increase the intensity of the fire and complicate the extinguishing works.
The resources provided by the Government of Aragón consist of the Calamocha heliborne brigade with its helicopter, two ground brigades, two fire engines, three technicians (one of them from the Support Group for the Extinction Director - GADEX), and two foremen.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-96P3-RT4F-V2NM-00000-00Two migrant firefighters arrested in the U.S. when .... they were putting out a forest fire!2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisTwo migrant firefighters arrested in the U.S. when .... they were putting out a forest fire!


Los Angeles - Washington Governor Bob Ferguson and Washington Senator Patty Murray, both Democrats, on Thursday condemned President Donald Trump's administration for the alleged arrest by immigration authorities of two forest firefighters who were working to contain a fire in that state.


The firefighters, who were members of a team attempting to contain the flames of the Bear Gulch Fire in the Olympic National Forest, were detained Wednesday by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Department of Natural Resources confirmed.
Ferguson said this morning that he is "deeply concerned about this situation" and has ordered an investigation into what happened.
For more than three hours, DHS agents demanded identification of members of two private contractor crews, who were among hundreds of firefighters, deployed to fight the wildfire, the largest active fire in Washington state, the Seattle Times reported.
As of Wednesday morning, the fire, located east of Seattle, covered nearly 3,642 hectares and was 13% contained.
The arrest of the firefighters also caused the outrage of Senator Murray, who also charged today against President Donald Trump's Administration and its campaign of mass deportations calling the policy "sick and perverse."
"This new Republican policy of detaining firefighters on the job is as immoral as it is dangerous," Murray added in a statement, in which she highlighted the importance of the work of firefighters in the face of fires, which in recent years have devastated entire towns on the West Coast of the United States.
This Thursday, the U.S.border policy czar, Tom Homan, warned that immigration operations would be intensified in sanctuary cities such as New York, Los Angeles, Portland or Seattle, all of them with policies that limit the collaboration of their police with immigration authorities.

urn:contentItem:6G35-1CJ3-S045-B3XX-00000-00Forest fire incidents in Ilocos Norte down 80.95% - BFP2025-06-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisForest fire incidents in Ilocos Norte down 80.95% - BFP

19 Jun 2025 (Philippines News agency) The Bureau of Fire Protection (BFP) in Ilocos Norte has recorded a significant drop in the number of forest fire incidents in the province in the first few months of 2025 compared to the same period last year.

In a statement Thursday, Fire Supt. Roxanne Annie Parado, Provincial Fire Marshal, said only eight forest fires had occurred since January this year, an 80.95-percent drop from the 42 incidents recorded during the same period in 2024.

"I would like to thank the real heroes in preventing forest fires in the province. There had been significant decline of forest fires because of the strong collaboration of the inter-agency task force," Parado said.

The task force is composed of representatives from the BFP, the Philippine National Police, Philippine Marine Corps, Philippine Air Force, Philippine Army, Department of Environment and Natural Resources, and the provincial government of Ilocos Norte.

Parado attributed the decrease in forest fires to the various pro-active measures being implemented such as the establishment of checkpoints, placement of trucks, water sourcing, and air assets, including conduct of regular patrolling of forested areas and hiring of more forest rangers.

During the dry season, local government units in forest fire-prone areas establish police checkpoints and a registry of civilians going to the mountains.

Honeybee collectors, wildlife hunters and "kaingeros" (those involved in slash-and-burn activities) were also given alternative livelihood through the government's social aid programs.

Parado said she is hoping that with continued public vigilance and support from concerned public and private stakeholders, hazardous fires would be prevented.

Record shows the wildfires in Ilocos Norte are mostly 'accidental fires' caused by dry weather, discarded lit cigarettes, open fires from campers or hikers, wildlife hunters, and the burning of agriculture wastes.

urn:contentItem:6GRG-9T43-RXF2-T2W6-00000-00Ecocide denounced in Holbox: fire devastated 670 hectares of protected forest2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisEcocide denounced in Holbox: fire devastated 670 hectares of protected forest


Mexico City - Civil society organizations made an urgent call to federal, state, municipal and agrarian authorities to investigate and punish the forest fire that was allegedly set last August on Holbox Island, Quintana Roo, within the coveted Yum Balam Flora and Fauna Protection Area, which devastated more than 670 hectares of jungle.


The Centro Mexicano de Derecho Ambiental (CEMDA), Grupo Ecológico del Mayab; Grupo Tortuguero del Caribe; Amigos de Sian Ka'an; Centinelas del Agua and Casa Wayuu, warned that a 20-year ban should be immediately decreed for the affected land, without the possibility of approving a change in land use, as established in the General Law of Sustainable Forest Development.
The NGOs recalled that last August 22, a forest fire broke out in the Punta Mosquito / La Ensenada area, to the northwest of Holbox, which was active for nine days and managed to be liquidated by the beginning of September.
They emphasized that the area impacted is the size of the Chapultepec Forest, which is the equivalent of 941 soccer fields or 143 skirting boards in Mexico City.
They emphasized that according to the Civil Protection of Quintana Roo, this forest fire was the only one registered out of season in the state during 2025.
The environmental organizations pointed out that the preliminary assessment of the damages can be summarized in the loss of key environmental services, since the fire caused the fragmentation of the ecosystem, since it practically divided the island from east to west, displacing fauna, destroying habitats, shelter and feeding areas.
It also destroyed mangroves, which are essential for coastal protection and erosion control, since they dissipate wave energy and protect inland.
"Mangroves also provide valuable environmental services such as the capture and storage of so-called blue carbon, as they trap two to four times more carbon than terrestrial forests. Their burning and degradation releases carbon dioxide (CO2) and reduces future sequestration capacity," they said.
They stated that the forest fire affected habitat and ecological connectivity, since Yum Balam integrates jungles, mangroves, dunes and wetlands that support life cycles (breeding, feeding, shelter) of multiple species.
Similarly, damage was caused to the flora, mainly in coastal scrub mangroves, "both in their coverage and structure, which implies a risk of mortality of seedlings/propagules and retreat of edges, as well as loss of associated ecosystem functions (filtration and sediment retention)".
Regarding impacts to fauna and their habitat, they emphasized that Punta Mosquito and the adjacent sandy areas are nesting and feeding sites for shorebirds and coastal birds, which are sensitive to disturbance and loss of cover.
"In Yum Balam there are emblematic species with habitats connected to the jungle-wetland-mangrove mosaic, such as sea turtles -white, loggerhead and hawksbill-, crocodiles (American and swamp crocodiles), birds such as the American flamingo, the reddish egret and the whistling and snowy plovers.
There are also mammals of high conservation value such as the jaguar, tapir, and manatee.
It should be noted that Ensenada de Holbox is the most important hawksbill turtle nesting beach in the state of Quintana Roo. The annual average number of nests in the last five years is 1,269, and it is one of the few beaches in the Caribbean with a positive trend in reproduction.
They added that with the temporary loss of vegetation cover, there is greater exposure of the soil to wind erosion in dunes and risk of ash dragging to nearby wetlands, with effects on water quality.

urn:contentItem:6GR7-5XV3-RVVJ-W42G-00000-00End of access restrictions to wooded areas in Pictou and Colchester counties2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisEnd of access restrictions to wooded areas in Pictou and Colchester counties

The risk of forest fire is now sufficiently low in the counties of Pictou and Colchester to end the restrictions on travel and activities in wooded regions, today September 11.

With this change, which comes into force at 4 p.m., half of the counties in the province are no longer subject to restrictions. The restrictions were lifted in the following counties on August 29:

The ban on lighting fires remains in force throughout the province until October 15, the date of the end of the forest fire season, or until the conditions improve more.

Our experts carefully monitors the conditions and are now up to us that it is now safe to remove restrictions on access to wooded regions in two other counties, says Prime Minister Tim Houston. I thank everyone for their efforts to prevent forest fires during this very difficult season. Every day, we get closer to a normal life for affected people. We particularly thank everyone who was touched by the Forest Fire of Long Lake, and I thank the teams who worked hard to fight the fire. >>>>

In the rest of the province, drought is always extreme and dangerous, and that is why the restrictions on access to wooded regions will remain in force until October 15 or until the conditions improve enough. The affected counties are as follows:

The fine for non-compliance with restrictions is 25,000.

"This requires the initiation of expert reports on the origin of the fire, the trajectories, as well as the damage to the wetlands.
Let us remember that, in Article 420 Bis of the Federal Penal Code, it is punishable to provoke fires in forests, jungles, natural vegetation and forest lands, with aggravating circumstances in Natural Protected Areas.
Decree and register the closure for 20 years, in accordance with the provisions of Article 97 of the General Law of Sustainable Forestry Development, regarding the prohibition to change the use of land on burned land until regeneration is proven.
Record the closure in the National Forestry Registry and coordinate with Public Property Registries, environmental logbook and agrarian authorities, preventive annotations that provide opposability and control of procedures.
Report the polygon to the Ministry of the Environment and Natural Resources (Semarnat), the National Water Commission (Conagua), the Federal Environmental Protection Agency (Profepa), the Quintana Roo Ministry of the Environment (SEMA), the Lázaro Cárdenas City Hall, and the agrarian authorities, so that they do not admit or grant permits, licenses, concessions, or procedures that contravene the closed season and the Protected Natural Area Management Program.
To carry out permanent publicity and surveillance, registering the case with an official map and coordinates of the affected area; to carry out continuous operations by land, sea and, during the critical season, by air; and to carry out a forest fire prevention campaign," they concluded.

urn:contentItem:6GS3-RCC3-RS97-73GY-00000-00One man evacuated to hospital after car on fire, which caused an outbreak of fire in Ronda2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisOne man evacuated to hospital after car on fire, which caused an outbreak of fire in Ronda


A man has been injured with burns after a car caught fire in the lane of the Finca Descalzos Viejos, in the neighborhood of La Dehesa, in the municipality of Ronda, Malaga. The vehicle was completely burned and the flames caused a forest fire in a nearby area of vegetation and pine forest.


The event took place on the afternoon of Monday, September 15, around 18:30 hours, as reported by the Emergency Service 112 Andalusia. The warning alerted that a car was burning at that point and that its driver was allegedly in place, affected by the flames. It was also reported that the fire was beginning to spread towards the natural environment.
After receiving the alert, the 112 quickly mobilized the firefighters of the Provincial Consortium of the Diputación de Málaga (CPB), members of the Infoca Plan, National Police, Local Police and medical services. Upon arrival, the firefighters managed to extinguish both the vehicle fire and the outbreak of forest fire.
According to the CPB, the fire affected about 500 square meters of vegetation and pine forest before being extinguished. Thanks to the rapid intervention of the emergency teams, the flames were prevented from spreading beyond the affected area.
The injured man was treated at the scene by the health services, who decided to transfer him to a hospital for evaluation and treatment, due to the burns suffered.

urn:contentItem:6GDH-J1T3-RTDB-F46B-00000-00President Prabowo Urges Accelerated Airport Construction Project and Forest Fire Mitigation2025-08-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisPresident Prabowo Urges Accelerated Airport Construction Project and Forest Fire Mitigation

01 Aug 2025 (Cabinet Secretariat of the Republic of Indonesia) President Prabowo Subianto Friday (08/01) led a joint limited meeting attended by a number of Red and White Cabinet ministers at his residence in Hambalang village, Bogor regency, West Java province, to discuss and monitor the updates on government work programs.

Cabinet Secretary Teddy Indra Wijaya in his written press statement mentioned that the meeting was held in a hybrid session attended by some ministers at the President's residence, while other ministers were participating through video conference.

Cabinet Secretary Teddy explained that President Prabowo, at the meeting, emphasized the significance of accelerating air transportation infrastructure to support inter-regional connectivity.

'The President urges to open as many international airports as possible in the regions in order to boost economic cycle and regional tourism,' Cabinet Secretary Teddy said.

In addition to transportation issue, President Prabowo also gave his directions to immediately prepare preventive measures for forest fires that could potentially occur due to hot climate.

'The Head of State also gave his direction on immediate preventive measures for potential forest fires due to hot climate. The discussion also covered updates on economic, agricultural, and marine sectors,' the Cabinet Secretary added.

urn:contentItem:6GGP-JHN3-RXWH-J47B-00000-00New Geography Findings from University of Ferhat Abbas Described (Assesing and maping forest fire risk in Bejaia, Algeria, using GIS tehnique and remote sensing)2025-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - GEOGRAPHYNew Geography Findings from University of Ferhat Abbas Described (Assesing and maping forest fire risk in Bejaia, Algeria, using GIS tehnique and remote sensing)


2025 AUG 13 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- Investigators publish new report on geography. According to news reporting out of Setif, Algeria, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Each year, Forest fires pose significant socio-economic and environmental challenges, particularly in Mediterranean regions."


Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from University of Ferhat Abbas: "In this respect, the wilaya of Bejaia, located in the northeastern part of Algeria, is an illustrative example of forest fires. In this study, we used multi-source remote sensing data (MODIS, Landsat 8) and the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform to assess and map the burn severity of forest fires that occurred in 2021. In addition, the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) and the Differenced Normalized Burn Ratio (dNBR) were applied to identify and analyze severity and extent of the damage. Results showed that approximately 15281.86 hectares, (4.69 % of the study area) were burned, with 7156.33 hectares classified as high-severity burns, mostly located in the northwestern part of the region, such as Adekar, El Kseur, and Kendera. Further analysis showed that topographical and environmental factors such as elevation, aspect and slope played a significant role in fire propagation."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This research shows how GIS and remote sensing can be valuable tools for policymakers in designing targeted strategies for fire prevention and mitigation in high-risk areas."
For more information on this research see: Assesing and maping forest fire risk in Bejaia, Algeria, using GIS tehnique and remote sensing. Glasnik Srpskog Geografskog Društva, 2025,105(1):273-286. (Glasnik Srpskog Geografskog Društva - http://www.doiserbia.nb.rs/journal.aspx?issn=0350-3593). The publisher for Glasnik Srpskog Geografskog Društva is Serbian Geographical Society.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.2298/GSGD2501273S.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Sallaye Miloud, Department of Geography and Territory Planning, Institute of Architecture and Earth Sciences, University of Ferhat Abbas, Setif, Algeria. Additional authors for this research include Belloulou Bilal, Khallef Boubaker.
Keywords for this news article include: University of Ferhat Abbas, Setif, Algeria, Africa, Geography, Remote Sensing, Science.

urn:contentItem:6GRW-S7Y3-RXG1-G3Y3-00000-00Five brigaders injured in a fire in Barreiros (Lugo), which has burned 80 hectares2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisFive brigaders injured in a fire in Barreiros (Lugo), which has burned 80 hectares


Five members of the firefighting brigades have been injured while fighting the forest fire declared this Sunday afternoon in the parish of San Xurxo de Cabarcos, in the municipality of Barreiros (Lugo), a fire that remains active on Monday.


The Consellería do Medio Rural de la Xunta de Galicia has reported that the fire has already burned about 80 hectares, according to the latest figures available.
The five injured brigadistas were initially evacuated to the Hospital Público da Mariña, in Burela, and later transferred to the burn unit of the Complexo Hospitalario Universitario da Coruña(Chuac), where they remain hospitalized, according to health sources confirmed to EFE.
A total of 23 agents, 31 brigades, 27 motor-pumps, 4 excavators, 4 technicians and two technical support units are working on the ground.
As for aerial resources, seven helicopters and three airplanes have been deployed to fight the flames.
Neighbors of the area of A Rexa have told EFE that the extinguishing teams had to work hard during the night to protect the houses, as the fire came dangerously close to the houses.
The intense smoke yesterday forced to cut the Cantabrian highway (A-8) and generated delays in the National Road 634.
Five members of the firefighting brigades have been injured while fighting the forest fire declared this Sunday afternoon in the parish of San Xurxo de Cabarcos, in the municipality of Barreiros (Lugo), a fire that continues active this Monday.

urn:contentItem:6GP7-TSB3-RVC4-B1NG-00000-00Researchers from Czech University of Life Sciences Prague Publish New Studies and Findings in the Area of Physics (Two-Year Post-Fire Abundance of Arthropod Groups Across Different Types of Forest in Temperate Central Europe)2025-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisPHYSICSResearchers from Czech University of Life Sciences Prague Publish New Studies and Findings in the Area of Physics (Two-Year Post-Fire Abundance of Arthropod Groups Across Different Types of Forest in Temperate Central Europe)


2025 SEP 08 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on physics. According to news originating from Prague, Czech Republic, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires are commonly regarded as negative for ecosystems; however, they also represent a major ecological force shaping the biodiversity of invertebrates and many other organisms. The aim of this study was to better understand how multiple groups of invertebrates respond to wildfire across different forest types in Central Europe."


Financial supporters for this research include Czech University of Life Sciences Prague, Faculty of Forestry And Wood Sciences; Ministry of Agriculture of The Czech Republic.
Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Czech University of Life Sciences Prague: "The research was conducted following a large forest fire (ca. 1200 ha) that occurred in 2022. Data were collected over two years (2023 and 2024), from April to September. The research was conducted in coniferous forests and included six pairwise study types: burnt and unburnt dead spruce (bark beetle affected), burnt and unburnt clear-cuts, and burnt and unburnt healthy stands. In total, 96 traps were deployed each year. Across both years, 220,348 invertebrates were recorded (1.Y: 128,323; 2.Y: 92,025), representing 24 taxonomic groups. A general negative trend in abundance following forest fire was observed in the groups Acari, Auchenorhyncha, Blattodea, Dermaptera, Formicidae, Chilopoda, Isopoda, Opiliones, and Pseudoscorionida. Groups showing a neutral response included Araneae, Coleoptera, Collembola, Diplopoda, Heteroptera, Psocoptera, Raphidioptera, Thysanoptera, and Trichoptera. Positive responses, indicated by an increase in abundance, were recorded in Hymenoptera, Orthoptera, Lepidoptera, and Diptera. However, considerable differences among management types (clear-cut, dead spruce, and healthy) were evident, as their distinct characteristics largely influenced invertebrate abundance in both unburnt and burnt variants of the types across all groups studied. Forest fire primarily creates favorable conditions for heliophilous, open-landscape, and floricolous invertebrate groups, while less mobile epigeic groups are strongly negatively affected. In the second year post-fire, the total invertebrate abundance in burnt sites decreased to 59% of the first year's levels."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Forest fire generates a highly heterogeneous landscape from a regional perspective, creating unique ecological niches that persist more than two years after fire. For many invertebrates, successional return toward pre-fire conditions is delayed or incomplete."
For more information on this research see: Two-Year Post-Fire Abundance of Arthropod Groups Across Different Types of Forest in Temperate Central Europe. Fire, 2025,8(8):305. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8080305.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Vaclav Zumr, Faculty of Forestry and Wood Sciences, Czech University of Life Sciences Prague, Kamycka 129, Praha 6-Suchdol, 165 00 Prague, Czech Republic. Additional authors for this research include Oto Nakladal, Jiri Remeš.
Keywords for this news article include: Czech University of Life Sciences Prague, Prague, Czech Republic, Europe, Ecology, Physics.

urn:contentItem:6G5Y-SG63-RS26-V0PX-00000-00Studies in the Area of Machine Learning Reported from Kangwon National University (Forest Fire Risk Prediction in South Korea Using Google Earth Engine: Comparison of Machine Learning Models)2025-07-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:26ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGStudies in the Area of Machine Learning Reported from Kangwon National University (Forest Fire Risk Prediction in South Korea Using Google Earth Engine: Comparison of Machine Learning Models)


2025 JUL 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Disease Prevention Daily -- Investigators publish new report on artificial intelligence. According to news originating from Chuncheon, South Korea, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires pose significant threats to ecosystems, economies, and human lives. However, existing forest fire risk assessments are over-reliant on field data and expert-derived indices."


Financial supporters for this research include Korea Government; Korea Forest Service.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Kangwon National University: "Here, we assessed the nationwide forest fire risk in South Korea using a dataset of 2289 and 4578 fire and non-fire events between 2020 and 2023. Twelve remote sensing-based environmental variables were exclusively derived from Google Earth Engine, including climate, vegetation, topographic, and socio-environmental factors. After removing the snow equivalent variable owing to high collinearity, we trained three machine learning models: random forest, XGBoost, and artificial neural network, and evaluated their ability to predict forest fire risks. XGBoost showed the best performance (F1 = 0.511; AUC = 0.76), followed by random forest (F1 = 0.496) and artificial neural network (F1 = 0.468). DEM, NDVI, and population density consistently ranked as the most influential predictors. Spatial prediction maps from each model revealed consistent high-risk areas with some local prediction differences."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "These findings demonstrate the potential of integrating cloud-based remote sensing with machine learning for large-scale, high-resolution forest fire risk modeling and have implications for early warning systems and effective fire management in vulnerable regions. Future predictions can be improved by incorporating seasonal, real-time meteorological, and human activity data."
For more information on this research see: Forest Fire Risk Prediction in South Korea Using Google Earth Engine: Comparison of Machine Learning Models. Land, 2025,14(6):1155. (Land - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/land). The publisher for Land is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/land14061155.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Jukyeong Choi, Department of Forestry and Environmental Systems, Kangwon National University, Chuncheon 24341, South Korea.
